Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Bipartite Temporal Event Network (BiTEN) Model

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will develop a powerful and flexible statistical modeling framework that facilitates the analysis of complex network data. This model, called the bipartite temporal event network (BiTEN) model, will allow researchers to tease apart finely grained temporal dynamics along with properties of network structure, spatial geography, and any given set attributes that describe actors and/or their relationships. Across a variety of disciplines, situations arise in which actors (e.g., individuals, organizations, states, etc.) form ties to entities (e.g., products, corporations, treaties). International environmental treaty ratification is an example of a complex process through which states connect to treaties via the decision to ratify. The questions surrounding treaty ratification lie at the heart of a science of networks and specifically speak to the phenomena of diffusion, contagion, and behavioral cascades. Understanding this process is critical to making progress on issues ranging from global warming to arms control. The researchers will apply this method to a number of substantive questions, including treaty ratification, the onset of war, transnational terrorism, the creation of legislation, consumer behavior, and peer influence among students. They also will develop and disseminate free and open source statistical software.

The researchers will develop a temporal process for the modeling of network dependencies that can accommodate the vital actor- and relationship- level effects. The statistical challenge in this project stems from the fact that the structure in which the actors tie to the entities affects subsequent ties. That is, the structure of the network of relationships may drive its own evolution -- a phenomena familiar in network science. The researchers will develop two estimation strategies for the model: a Bayesian approach and a maximum likelihood approach. The models developed will reliably estimate what portions of a phenomenon are driven by latent state network structure, actor attributes, relational attributes, spatial geography, and temporal dynamics. The models also will leverage all of these dynamics to probabilistically predict link formation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Longitudinal bipartite network data is comprised of temporal events between pairs of entities of two distinct types.  For example, environmental treaty ratifications can be represented as a longitudinal bipartite network, where countries and treaties represent the two types of entities (i.e. “nodes” in the network) and a connection (i.e. “link” in the network) exists between a given country and treaty once the treaty is ratified by the country. While the amount of bipartite temporal event network data continues to increase in a number of the sciences, there was a lack of statistical methodology available to appropriately analyze such data.  

 

This work contributes a powerful new statistical modeling framework, called the Bipartite Longitudinal Influence Network (BLIN) model, that allows a researcher to infer influence networks capturing dependence between entities of the same type.  In the context of the environmental treaties data, this methodology infers a country-country network quantifying the degree of “influence” between each pair of countries.  The influence measures quantify how likely country X is to sign a given treaty given country Y recently signed that same treaty.  A treaty-treaty network is also estimated that quantifies for each pair of treaties A and B how likely a country is to sign a treaty A given the country recently signed treaty B.  The model parsimoniously parameterizes these complex dependences, such that estimation of model parameters is feasible from data with a low signal-to-noise ratio and the estimated parameters are interpretable. Properties of the proposed model have been compared to existing models both in simulation and analytically to illustrate the strengths of the proposed methods. 

 

The proposed methodology has application across many substantive areas, ranging from the social and economic sciences to neuroscience and beyond. The method was specifically used in the context of environmental treaties to estimate underlying dependencies among countries and understand how these dependencies affect ratifications. We used this tool to understand international collective action on one of the most pressing policy problems of our time: the protection of the environment and the mitigation of climate change. We have also used this tool to understand the proliferation of human rights norms from country to country. The newly developed methods and demonstrations of the methods on various data sets are described in publically available manuscripts and have been presented at a range of national and international disciplinary and interdisciplinary conferences and workshops.
